snippet.textDisplay:
Randomised anonymous number assigned to all voters each election. Results with this number only published in full for anyone to check their number went to the correct person.

Only this publishing number randomised each time, you still have a voter number as normal, so it can be published publicly without any issues.

Given these results are then fully verifiable by every single voter, results with any real problems have little chance of not been found.

snippet.textDisplay:
The problem with machine voting, in essence, is that you end up putting a LOT of votes in ONE person's control - whether a hacker, a programmer, or an election official... And then ballot anonymity helps them cover up mistakes or fraud.

This is also why you never should transport paper ballots or leave them. Paper elections should have enough resources to be finished in one evening, ideally, with mail-in ballots being a necessary flaw in the system, not a secure convenience.

snippet.textDisplay:
As a computer engineering student, I have a different idea of what "electronic voting" would be. I think in general, electronic voting is viewed as convenient and dependent on software. I view it more as, it should be hardware dependent. In hardware design, there is something called an antifuse. Basically, if you run a high enough current through an antifuse, the antifuse "breaks" and permanently forces a "short circuit" which is the opposite of a fuse(which is to permanently open the circuit). This tech is used to "program" FPGA gates very quickly. It could also be used for security purposes. The right hardware architecture would ensure that no tampering could be done, or at least, it would be very difficult. You wouldn't be able to change the outcome of the input. Theoretically, you could make a physical electronic device that is extremely tamper resistant that could even program itself so long as a voltage source and ground are provided. The weak link is reading the results from the device. It would have to be plugged into a compatible port, but the good news is you can't try to change the results because if you tried, it would destroy the circuit essentially. This kind of hardware is actually easily mass produced, and probably resides in some of your home electronics you don't even know had computers in them... like your stove, microwave, fridge, thermostat, etc.


Unfortunately, that idea is neither cheap nor convenient, although I think it would still be very inexpensive on a larger scale considering the cost of that hardware drops to less than a penny per device in large enough quantities. And it is also open to other kinds of attacks. Say for instance, someone gets ahold of 1000 of the devices, and puts the same vote on them all, and somehow manages to sneak them all into a ballot box(or wherever these are being stored). Though, I think that problem is solved with serial numbers. The devices would have to be distributed at random, only at voting centers. You'd be able to trace what serials are at what voting centers, but not what box it is in, or who used them.


Just my thoughts, I'm not a security expert though. I know secure hardware is becoming more of a thing these days, so I'm sure someone has a better idea. And I'm sure someone can think of a way to compromise my idea. I don't think a physical device would really be an upgrade over the way we vote now tbh.

snippet.textDisplay: You CAN trace votes in a UK election. Every ballot paper has a number; the number is recorded against your name on the polling station's list; the lists and the ballot papers are kept for a year and a day in sacks in a warehouse. How secure is that warehouse? No idea. And don't forget that you need no ID (or even your polling card) to vote.

snippet.textDisplay: 5:43 India does that, we do take the machines physically(in sealed condition) to a central counting place. There is also a VVPAT system( A physical paper audit trail) that is generated like a physical ballot box and every voter can see it if matches with what they had originally voted for. Ideally, these VVPAT paper trails can be physically counted to see if they match the electronic count, which kills the purpose of Electronic voting anyway. So, they are randomly sampled from different booths to see the consistency. So, what do you think of that Tom?

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm not entirely convinced..
Aside from the explaining to people about blockchain, I think it could practically work.
Yes, it does have the problem that if you can check it, then someone can try and influence you.
However, they would have to actually get your private key which you use to check it to do that.
That would take a lot of manpower to pressure enough people to vote a specific way, as they would have to get the private key off everyone.
Aside from that, it doesn't really matter what device you use to submit your vote, as long as you can check it afterwards.
I also think you could set permissions on who gets to actually view your vote.
Like you need your secret password plus your unique key.
You could then just give a different password if someone wanted to pressure you to check your vote.


Also, as for the machine checking the votes, well every PC could check the votes as well, with all sorts of open source software to verify the count.


Just saying, I think there's ways around it all, as long as the actual data remains visible and disassociated with the users without the key.

snippet.textDisplay:
The premise that anonymity is fundamental to protecting election validity is fundamentally flawed. By way of example: aerospace industry safety and reliability is successfully predicated on parts traceability. Without traceability, authorities would not know who's parts broke and parts makers would not know if it was their parts that crashed a plane. If you need a high reliability system, then that system needs to be auditable. Democratic elections today are, for the most part, not auditable from their sourcd, the voters.

The solution, here, is a mechanism to make voters accountable for their votes in the same way that their agents, the representatives must cast open votes. Voter anonymity is antithetical to reliability of election results. We have seen this repeatedly in countries around the world. It can happen in any country! You need to think about the cost of buying individual voters. It's not worth doing when the interests can simply and a lot more cheaply, buy one vote on the two issues they care about during a representative's term. Why buy the cow when you 8 by need two cups of milk a year!

Centralized voting with source data publicly available for tally is the way to add traceability and auditable to elections. We have the technology and capability. Now, we must use it for good!

Your scare tactic about prejudice and discrimination on the basis of political affiliation is probably illegal in most demicracies, so that's not really a legitimate complaint.

I'm not saying that only electronic voting will solve this traceability problem, but adding source traceability is the way to make electronic voting both viable and reliable.

snippet.textDisplay:
One of the primary arguments for electronic voting is not really an argument for electronic voting at all - accessibility.
It boggles the mind to think how difficult some countries make it to vote. In the USA their most important elections happen on a Tuesday. The UK is going to a general election on a Thursday.
In Australia, elections are held on a Saturday, at local community centres (usually Primary Schools) - but we also have mandatory voting, so there's more need to vote too.

snippet.textDisplay:
I don’t know. I already don’t trust physical voting. While there are undoubtedly many issues with electronic voting, it seems like it mostly seems like a bad idea because it’s not what we’re currently doing so all the challenges it poses are new and unconfronted. I’m sure if we implemented electronic voting there would be a few problems, but then we’d get it sorted (mostly).

And as far the anonymity thing goes, couldn't there be a way to check that the software correctly recorded and sent your vote after the fact while keeping that information private? Like with a secure login/account. So at the very least there would need to be some new division of the government whose job is to maintain voter security, but I don’t think it’s entirely not doable.

snippet.textDisplay:
The trust aspect is critical, but the anonymity? That's actually an open question.


Anonymity has been steadily reducing over the years. Social media, personalized ads, Ring cams, and digital assistants all shown just how little the public actually cares about Big Brother.


Is that a situation ripe for abuse? Yes. We did see election tampering via social media just recently here in the States. However there's a case to be made that it's not the access to specific demographics, but rather the gross negligence and novelty of the attack which are the cause.


Maintaining complete anonymity on voting in some sense could be equated to an argument for banning any political identification on social media or other online venues. It holds anonymity to such a high ideal that it stymies the actual goal of sending the vote/free speech.


Discriminating based on vote history should be prohibited, clearly. But we can already be discriminated based on many other factors such as race, sex, age, etc. That information for some reason is not handled with the same black box treatment. Yet society seems to function quite well overall, despite some opportunity for abuse and the policing it requires.


Given this, I think ultimately we will be giving up anonymous voting for the convenience and trust we get in return.

snippet.textDisplay:
In Argentina (only on the capital) they implemented a pseudo electronic voting where the machine will use a laser printer to write your vote into the valet and it will add it's value to an RFID chip that allowed for faster and more precise counting of the votes. Then it was transmitted though internet so the results can be broadcast a few hours after finished the election.
Then all the valets where sealed and send to the counting place where they counted what was printed and not the chips (for obvious reasons) and this was the actual final and valid result.
This method speeds ups the results and is as trustworthy as regular voting. (It has the same problems)
Source: I worked as part of the technical team preparing the election.

snippet.textDisplay: Here's a question; what about a purely hardwired system? Devices without programmable chips but soldered transistors unable to reprogrammed? Assuming each voting machine  can be verified by multiple parties before it's sealed means that it doesn't require everyone to know how it works, it would only require the same level of trust as when votes are counted. Of course this doesn't solve a lot of the problems with electronic voting but it's interesting thought of a step in the correct direction for more secure single use devices.

Building a system everyone can trust is in my opinion, not only not a goal to strive for in voting systems, but a goal that is unachievable in any system because at the end of the day, for the average person it comes down to having faith.

snippet.textDisplay:
Hey, @Tom.

I'm Brazillian and here we use electronic voting since 1996.


Of course electronic voting is not 100% secure, as paper voting isn't.


Here we use 2 separate machines that isn't connected to the internet at all. They run offline all the time and will never be connected to the internet. These 2 machines did not communicate to each other in any way, as well.


So, machine 1 is used by the mesarys (guys in the polling station to make sure that you are you voting) just to count how many people voted in the section. They check your ID matching to a paper with all the names in the section, then allow you to vote in the cabin.
Machine 2 is the polling machine itself. Once allowed, you can go to this machine (it's important to say that this machine is not associated to the other in any way, so it doesn't record any personal data or identification from the user) and vote.


Before the voting starts both of these machines print a zero log (which is a log showing that both machines are empty in the beginning). Once the voting ends, both machines print a log, machine 1 showing how many people voted in this section, machine two with the voting numbers (eg. candidate 1 --- x votes; candidate 2 --- y votes; etc; All votings in this section --- z votes). The number in machine 1 and 2 should match.


Then the machines are PHISICALLY transported with one representative guy of each party + neutral fiscals. Once they reach the electoral justice, the dump the data and count the total voting, as well they publish in the internet. But remember, all of the data can be verified in the voting section, once they have printed and posted publicaly in the section. Anyone can verify and report any incident.


To hack one of these machines, the hacker should get physical access to the machine (btw, these machines have NO inputs unlocked). The source code is opened to public access before the elections and intensely tested all around the world. So even if the hacker get physical access, should be a painful job hack one of these machines.

And to make sure the data is not compromise due to tracking, all the data is mixed every vote.

I mean, for sure is not 100% safe, but I can trust this procedure. For me this is as safe as or even more safe than paper voting.

snippet.textDisplay:
As a gov't employee I have helped with local and national elections in Belgium, with electronic voting and a lot of care is used to avoid fraud. The computers itself are locked physically, no accessible USB ports without a key, and those USB ports are very weirdly shaped (and deep) that a regular USB stick wouldn't fit.

People select their votes and get a unique qr code printed out, (every election a slightly different colour of paper to avoid fraud)

They also aren't connected to the internet, but the chairman of the voting place stores every vote in a sealed ballot box after it is scanned. And those can also be tallied if anyone doubts the results.

If you want to tamper with electronic voting, it'd be more difficult than you explain.

snippet.textDisplay: Voting machines, which you seem to waste so much time on, are a bad idea.  Electronic voting is a great idea.  The software used should be Chrome, Firefox, etc.. snippet.textDisplay:
I've been to a vote counting for local government as a volunteer, checking papers and counting them. It's FAR from secured. The officials there were obviously corrupted and in favor of one particular party - the one in place, counting multiple papers in the same envelope as multiple votes, counting marked papers as valid, counting torn papers as valid...


They also gathered up the counts table by table, but only one official at a time, most of the others staying between themselves and chatting. No one can affirm with full confidence that the numbers reported by that guy, the same one that was accepting obvious voided votes, were original and non-tampered with. Even the ballot that was in the room for us to count the votes already had broken seals when we were allowed to enter the counting room...


I can only attest that I, personally, have counted a large majority of valid votes going to the opposition but the party in place officially won by a landslide. I'm not saying that ALL of the counting rooms were that corrupt, but I'm saying it's very, very easy for parties to fraud their elections, especially with the current voting system.

snippet.textDisplay:
Bad idea at the moment... yes. But it's not impossible, I just don't think electronic voting can be done with common PCs.
Let's not forget that most security (both electronic and physical) is based on the "It's good enough" principle. Take internet banking, encrypted ssl connections, two factor authentication and fraud detection algorithms. It's a lot easier to con someone into transferring money to you themselves than hacking into their account and doing it yourself. The weak link has shifted to human vulnerabilities.
You could try to hack an e-voting machine, or you could just spread a load of targeted lies that you know that half of the population would believe.

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm sorry, but using the 2007 Scottish Parliament example to argue against e-counting is a bit silly. The problem was that the returning officer didn't add all the SNP regional vote results from the five different counting areas on the spreadsheet, and did the divisor calculation wrongly for the regional seats - in other word, it was a human error. They've stopped machine counting Scottish Parliament elections, but as the ballots are still counted in different locations, there is nothing about hand counting that will prevent a returning officer from incorrectly adding up the returns.

Also, the Councils always release the regional results by constituency after the elections on their own websites, so even if the Returning Officer's error hadn't been spotted before the declaration, it would have been spotted when the Councils posted the results online and rectified before the MSPs had even been sworn in.
